The door is locked.\. You look through a small window,
and see a few shadows moving.
This is Mr. Greene.\. You don't seem to remember anybody
with his name at school, but his face seems familiar,
and you faintly remember a counseling session with him.
\n<Sebastian>Not much.\. Why are you down here,\. though?
\n<Sebastian>I understand my mom being here,\. but I feel
like you'd want to be somewhere else.
\n<Mr. Greene>Eh...\. I feel like this place is alright for me.
\n<Mr. Greene>After all,\. this is your story.
\n<Mr. Greene>You know exactly what I mean.
\n<Mr. Greene>You can keep running as much as you want,\. but
eventually, you'll have to stop.\.\. You'll get tired,\.
and that's when it'll catch up to you.
\n<Mr. Greene>Your friends will come to their senses.\. This place
\n<Mr. Greene>You act like you don't know what I'm talking about.
\n<Mr. Greene>But deep down, it's only a matter of time.
\n<Mr. Greene>If we examine my existence here,\. the logical thing to
do would be to make you feel at home here,\. so I
\n<Mr. Greene>But I see something more in you, Sebby.\. Therefore,\.
I'm willing to answer any questions you may have.
\n<Mr. Greene>Eventually,\. maybe if I tell you enough,\. you'll have
the courage to leave this place yourself.
What would you like to talk about?
What would you like to ask?
How did we end up here?

\n<Mr. Greene>I'm not entirely sure how we got here.
\n<Mr. Greene>However, I can say this with certainty:\. you'll have a

\n<Mr. Greene>It'll be your choice to take it or not.
